The observation that an impoverished environment may alter the expectations and behavior of those who live within it is important. But the "culture of poverty" arguments were discredited for a good reason and we should not celebrate their return. Once we accept the premise that poor people are culturally inferior it is easy to blame them for their circumstances and use this as an excuse to cut programs that offer a way out. The so-called "structural" explanations of poverty that were offered as a response to the culture of poverty literature recognize that the impoverished environments that lead to despair are shaped by public policies and larger economic forces. Research that helps us understand why the United States has such a shameful geographic concentration of poverty should not be replaced by misguided efforts that blame poor people for their plight.

This is a great overview of changes in the field of sociology, but I see two omissions.  First, sociologists are not as uniformly liberal as this article makes it sound; political causes alone could have made some explanations unpopular, but they would not have driven them out entirely.  The reason cultural explanations of poverty had disappeared entirely was a general 15- or 20-year absence of culture from sociological theory.  While the Moynihan return certainly contributed to this, the absence had as much to do with the behaviorist logic of describing human action by reference to outside stimuli (the reason such explanations are appealing is that they rest on objectively measurable and easily quantifiable features of the environment, and can thus provide for more convincing explanation).  The second major omission of this article has to do with the reason for its return.  While generational change undoubtedly contributes, it too corresponds with a general shift in how sociologists view action.  Paralleling a shift from behaviorism to cognitivism in psychology, sociologists since the 1980's started developing a cognitive understanding of culture works.  The earliest work in this tradition saw culture as a cognitive product that can be created, transferred and used like a tool in a toolkit ("like a piece of software" would be a more familiar contemporary metaphor).  It is the work in this tradition that brought culture of poverty back to the table--and indeed, its insistence that culture is something that "people use" instead of "people are" can seem like pussyfooting around the topic.  But the more recent incarnations of this theory are far more straightforward: they view cultural learning as something that gradually alters fundamental aspects of social cognition, such as what seems desirable or moral.  Research by scholars like Stephen Vaisey shows, for example, that moral values explain a large portion of adolescent drug use even when all the major economic and social differences are taken into account.  So, this is indeed something of a return to where sociological theory was decades ago, and where lay intuition always remained.  However, this does not mean the discipline went full circle: both structural explanations and "cultural toolkit" explanations are still powerful, and will remain on the scene.  But it does mean that quantitative sociologists are having to figure out new ways of measuring beliefs and values-- culture is far harder to deal with objectively than something like socioeconomic standing.

To commenter #8 ("dab"):

"wealth of opportunity"? Kids growing up in poor areas receive an unconscionably low quality of education compared to those in richer districts. In this country, education IS opportunity and the poor don't get it.

I was a teacher in a very poor, urban district and I completely disagree with your assessment of parent involvement. Most of my student's parents cared greatly about their children's educations. If I had a hard time reaching them, it was because they were working 2 jobs because minimum wage is not enough to support a family. If a parent was reluctant to come to a meeting (VERY rare) it was because they had a well-placed distrust of schools, or were embarrassed at their own low-level of education. And of course wealthy parents can help out more in class! They have jobs that allow them to take paid time off!

When I read about the study where a researcher dropped an envelope on the street, and used the rate at which it was returned as an indicator, I laughed.

It made me remember the story about the man who was arrested by the NYPD because he picked up an unattended wallet. The wallet was placed by the NYPD as a decoy to entrap people. Here's the NYTimes story for those who doubt me: http://www.nytimes.com...

No doubt, in some areas, people may be more afraid of getting arrested by a police force looking to fulfill an arrest quota than they would be at getting the envelope mailed back.
